©1995-2007 Gazetteer for Scotland
Located on the northern tip of the Black Isle
column2: on the southern shore of the Cromarty Firth
column3: Cromarty sits 15 miles (24 km) northeast of Inverness. The town is the seat of the Urquhart family whose castle stands on a hill overlooking it. The town was an important trade port and as such was granted royal burgh status but as the port declined
column4:
the costs of retaining this status became too expensive.

In 1772
column5: George Ross of Pitkerie bought the town and began a programme of spending to redevelop it. He built a new harbour to encourage the fishing trade
column9: lace and a brewery. He also built many of the towns buildings including the Gaelic Church and Cromarty House (1772) which still exist today. With the development of better road and rail links through the Highlands
column10:
Cromarty again faced a drop in fortunes as new routes bypassed the Black Isle. This led to a downturn in the fishing industry and a subsequent drop in the town's population.

Town and County councils
column11:
the Civic Trust and the National Trust for Scotland are all working together to develop Cromarty in a similar way to Culross and create a conservation village. The town is regarded as the best preserved 18th Century town in the Highlands.

Cromarty is the birthplace of Hugh Miller
column15: is now a museum run by the National Trust for Scotland. Next door is the George Ross Court House
column16: which houses an award winning museum that highlights life
column18: within the town. Adjacent to that is a library donated by the Scottish philanthropist
